did.abstract: The Packer Collegiate Institute was incorporated in 1845 as the Brooklyn Female Academy, an institution devoted solely to female education. After the destruction of its original building in 1853, the Academy reopened in 1854 as the Packer Collegiate Institute, named after former Academy trustee William S. Packer. Packer became a coeducational institution in 1972, and remains one of Brooklyn's most well-known private schools. The Packer Collegiate Institute collection spans the period 1846 to 2002 and contains school publications and ephemera documenting Packer's history and programs.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Packer Collegiate Institute was incorporated in 1845 as the Brooklyn Female Academy, an institution devoted solely to female education. The Academy opened in 1846 in a building on Joralemon Street between Court and Clinton Streets in the present-day neighborhood of Brooklyn Heights. While it enjoyed consistently increasing enrollment over the years, the Academy was destroyed by fire on January 1, 1853.

Shortly after the Academy's destruction, Harriet Putnam Packer, widow of one of the Academy's trustees, William S. Packer, donated $65,000 toward the building of a new school, with the only stipulation being that it be named in honor of her late husband. In November of 1854, the Packer Collegiate Institute opened on the site of its forebear institution in a building designed in the Gothic Revival style by noted architect Minard LeFever.

Like its predecessor, Packer was an all-girls educational institution offering primary, secondary, and collegiate-level programs. For over a century, Packer remained one of New York City's foremost establishments for female education, and as its enrollment and curriculum expanded, new facilities were continually added to its distinctive campus. In 1972, in recognition of modern changes in private education, Packer altered its traditional course and became a coeducational institution.
As of 2010, Packer remains one of Brooklyn's highly regarded private schools, offering programs for preschool through the 12th grade on its now-landmarked campus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains four bound volumes of annual catalogs for the Brooklyn Female Academy/Packer Collegiate Institute, 1846 to 1882, as well as copies of individual catalogs for the periods 1849 to 1877 and 1883 to 1965. Also included is a general prospectus for the 1988 to 1989 school year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

physdesc.extent: in four bound volumes, six folders, and several loose publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains news publications produced by Brooklyn Female Academy/Packer alumnae. Materials include a bound volume of issues of the The Messenger Bird, 1849 to 1850; three bound volumes of issues of The Packer Alumna, 1885 to 1913; and individual issues of The Packer Alumna, 1877 and 1913 to 1982 (the title of this publication changed to The Packer Alumni between 1977 and 1980). Also included are published lists of Packer associated alumnae, 1901 to 1922, and a brochure related to Packer's donation campaign, 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains three Packer yearbooks for the years 1894, 1896, and 1916.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains three volumes of The Packer Hymnal for the years 1895, 1899, and 1961, and a collection of songs in three volumes titled Part-Songs for Female Voices, 1887.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains various Packer newsletters conveying information on Packer activities and events. Included are issues of The Packer Press, 1953 to 1965; one issue of The Packer Herald, 1987; one issue of Panorama, 1995; issues of The Packer Magazine, 1988 to 1999; and one issue of Building on Success, 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications created for various Packer events. Materials include graduation commencement exercise programs, available intermittently between the years 1896 and 1909, and one commencement exercise program for the year 1924. Programs for dinners, concerts, and celebratory events are also available intermittently between the years 1906 and 1958. Also included are addresses delivered by speakers at significant ceremonies, including the opening of the Brooklyn Female Academy in 1846, the Academy's reopening as the Packer Collegiate Institute in 1854, Packer's centennnial celebration in 1954, and the conclusion of Packer's 122nd year in 1967. Finally, the series contains two playscripts from the years 1859 and 1864.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains two annual reports of the Brooklyn Female Academy. The first is from the year 1847 and is supplemented with the Academy's act of incorporation, articles of association, and bylaws, as well as a list of stockholders. The second is from 1850 and is supplemented with proceedings of the Academy's stockholders.
